idiom: น้ำขึ้นให้รีบตัก
literal_meaning: When the water rises, hurry to scoop it up.
figurative_meaning: Take advantage of opportunities when they arise.
example: You should invest now; น้ำขึ้นให้รีบตัก.

idiom: ตีเหล็กต้องตีตอนร้อน
literal_meaning: Strike the iron while it's hot.
figurative_meaning: Act when the opportunity is favorable.
example: If you want to start your business, remember to ตีเหล็กต้องตีตอนร้อน.

idiom: เสียน้อยเสียมาก
literal_meaning: Lose a little, lose a lot.
figurative_meaning: Better to lose a little now than a lot later.
example: It's better to fix the small problem now; เสียน้อยเสียมาก.

idiom: พูดมากทำมาก
literal_meaning: Talk a lot, do a lot.
example: Don't just talk about your plans; พูดมากทำมาก and show results.

figurative_meaning: Someone who is deceitful or two-faced.
example: Be careful of him; he's a นกสองหัว who will betray you.

idiom: ไม่เห็นโลงศพไม่หลั่งน้ำตา
literal_meaning: Not shedding tears until seeing the coffin.
figurative_meaning: People often don't realize the seriousness of a situation until it's too late.
example: He never took his health seriously; ไม่เห็นโลงศพไม่หลั่งน้ำตา.

idiom: ข้าวใหม่ปลามัน
figurative_meaning: A newly married couple or something in its prime.
example: Their relationship is still fresh; they're in the ข้าวใหม่ปลามัน phase.

idiom: จับเสือมือเปล่า
literal_meaning: To catch a tiger with bare hands.
example: Trying to negotiate with him is like จับเสือมือเปล่า; it's nearly impossible.

idiom: ช้างเท้าหลัง
figurative_meaning: To be in an awkward or difficult position.
example: After that mistake, he felt like ช้างเท้าหลัง at work.
